Description: Mould-made scaraboid in Egyptian blue; back in the form of a ram's head, well-modelled, with forward curving horns, face and muzzle clearly shown, no ears and 'mane' behind horns across top of neck indicated by parallel incisions; underside decorated with an incised representation of winged horse Pegasus, flying to right, and unidentified object at bottom of field; pierced for suspension through diameter near the circular base, so head would hang down; in bright blue paste, of hard and coarse texture.
Production date: 600 BC - 570 BC (mainly, according to Webb forthcoming)
Curator's comments: Scaraboids in the shape of a ram's head pertain to a common series produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). They are normally made in Egyptian blue, like here. The ram's head reproduces the rhyton shape popular in both Greek coroplastic and coins. This shape can also be related to the ram-headed god Amun-Ra of Baded, the main local Egyptian god revered at Naukratis. Pegasus, represented on the base, is one of the most famous mythical creatures of the Greek mythology. Such Hellenising motifs are popular on scarabs and scaraboids produced at Naukratis. This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, see especially C14 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 144)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 125-126, Type XXXIV C14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.11) (phase 3)
